content:
CompSci 260P: Fundamentals of Algorithms with Applications

  • Class Meetings (Fall 2019)
    • Lecture:   Tu Th 3:30-4:50pm in MSTB 118
          no lecture on Tuesday Oct 15 (due to religious holidays)
    • Discussion:   F 3:00-3:50pm in MSTB 118

  • Instructor
    • Professor Dan Hirschberg  —  dan (at) ics.uci.edu
          office hours by appointment in DBH 4226
          instructor unavailable Oct 9,14-15,21-22 (due to religious holidays)
    • Teaching Assistant:     Martha Osegueda — mosegued (at) uci.edu
                                                  office hour TBA
    • Reader :                      Satish Kotti — skotti (at) uci.edu

  • Prerequisites
    • An undergraduate algorithms course

  • Add/Drop Policy
    • No adds or drops allowed after the second week of classes

  • Textbook
    • Required: Kleinberg and Tardos, Algorithm Design, Addison Wesley, 2006
      The course will cover the first seven chapters of this book

  • List of Topics
    The following schedule is approximate and may change over the course of the quarter.
    • Week 0-1: Introduction. The Stable Marriage Problem. [KT Chapter 1]
    • Weeks 1-2: Basics of Algorithm Analysis. [KT Chapter 2]
    • Weeks 2-3: Basics of Graph Algorithms. [KT Chapter 3]
      Week 4: First midterm examination covers chapters 1-3
    • Weeks 4-5: Greedy Algorithms. Shortest Paths. Minimum Spanning Trees. [KT Chapter 4]
    • Week 6: Divide and Conquer. [KT Sections 5.1-5.6, 13.5]
    • Weeks 7-8: Dynamic Programming. [KT Sections 6.1-6.9]
      Week 8: Second midterm examination covers chapters 4-6
    • Week 9: Network Flow. [KT Sections 7.1-7.7]
    • Week 10: Introduction to Linear Programming.
      Week 11: Comprehensive final examination

  • Notes — password-protected
      • user name is your UCInetID in ALL CAPS
      • password is your 8-character student number
    Students are responsible for all material covered in lecture and the relevant portions of the textbook, even if it does not appear in the lecture notes
    • Lecture Slides

  • Grading
    • 10% – homework assignments   —   lowest homework score is dropped
    • 20% – two projects
    • 30% – two midterms
    • 40% – final examination
    • 2% added to course average if student completes Course Evaluation

  • Homework, Project, and Exam Schedule

  • Discussion Board
    • Students can discuss matters related to this course on Piazza

  • Academic Dishonesty
    • Instances of academic dishonesty will be reflected in the final grade (usually an F)
      because dishonesty devalues the learning experience for the whole class.
      Additional consequences may occur at the campus level.
    • Examples of academic dishonesty include, but are not limited to:
      • copying from others during an examination
      • allowing another student to copy from your work
      • communicating exam answers to other students during an examination
      • using unauthorized materials during an examination
      • tampering with an examination after it has been corrected and then returning it for more credit
    • For more complete information about academic honesty policies, consult the
      Academic Senate Policy on Academic Integrity

  • Communication
    If you send me email with course-related questions:
    • include the string "CompSci 260P" at the start of the subject line
    • include your name and UCI Student ID number in the message
    • if you are not writing from your official UCI email address, please cc your official UCI email address

    (This protocol enables me to weed out requests for help on problems from non-UCI students)
Last modified: Oct 3, 2019
